Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Collaborative Research: Versatile Locomotion: From Walking to Dexterous Climbing with a Human-Scale Robot

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims to give legged robots the skills to navigate a wide variety of terrain. This capability is needed to employ robots in applications such as search-and-rescue, construction, and exploration of remote environments on Earth and other planets. The multidisciplinary team, composed of researchers at Duke, Stanford, UC Santa Barbara, JPL, and Motiv Robotics, will develop a robot to climb a variety of surfaces ranging from flat ground to overhanging cliffs. Using an array of sensors, unique hands, and sophisticated algorithms, the robot will dynamically adopt walking, crawling, climbing, and swinging strategies to traverse wildly varied terrain. During the course of this research, the team hopes to achieve the milestone of the first demonstration of a human-scale rock climbing robot. The research is also expected to lead to insights into cognitive and biomechanical processes in human and animal locomotion.

Although rock climbing serves as an ideal proving ground for the work, this project conducts basic research to address more a general-purpose goal; namely, to provide the physical and cognitive skills for robots to adaptively navigate varied terrain. It takes a dexterous climbing approach, which uses non-gaited, coordinated sequences of contact to move the body, much as dexterous manipulation uses contact with the fingers and palm to move an object. It will apply principles from optimization, machine learning, bioinspiration, and control theory to make intellectual contributions in several domains, such as robot hand design, planning algorithms, balance strategies, and locomotion performance measurement. Novel grippers, sensor-based planning strategies, reactive maneuvers, and locomotion metrics will be developed during the course of this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was part of a collaboration among Duke University, U.C. Santa Barbara and Stanford to develop hardware and control and motion planning software to enable a human-scale multi-limbed robot to traverse difficult terrain including steep slopes and nearly vertical rock faces. The specific goal of the Stanford contribution was to develop novel end-effectors and related control and sensing methods that enable a heavy, legged robot to climb steep rocky surfaces. The hardware and software were tested initially at Stanford and later at NASA JPL.

The project culminated in the design and fabrication of a new end-effector for the RoboSimian quadruped at JPL. The end-effector design employs a combination of spines on the phalanges of fingers and on a particle-jamming palm that conforms to rough surfaces (Fig. 1, left). The spines make contact with asperities (small bumps or pits) on the rock surface to generate high shear forces with little normal force. However, each spine/surface contact can only sustain a small fraction of the required load for a heavy robot. Therefore, the end-effector has mechanisms for load-sharing both among the phalanges and among spines in the compliant palm.

The two load sharing mechanisms are focused on the fingers and palm of the hand respectively. The phalanges are actuated through the use of a six-way tendon differential based on the concept of a whiffletree mechanism (Fig. 2). One tendon routes to each phalange, applying an approximately equal force to each array of spines. To promote load sharing among spines in the palm, we use a change of state as the granular medium in the palm switches from fluid to solid, under vacuum. The palm is first pressed into contact with the surface to be grasped and then lightly loaded in the shear direction. This causes small displacements along the surface, allowing the embedded microspines to travel until they find asperities. Next, a vacuum is applied to the central chamber, locking the palm into a rigid state and greatly increasing the stiffness of the spine supports  via particle jamming (Fig. 3). This process helps to ensure that a substantial fraction of the spines is engaged, thereby increasing the maximum palm forces available for climbing.

Tests conducted at JPL on the Surrogate platform (a two-armed variant of RoboSimian) confirm that the end-effector can sustain large tangential forces on surfaces, sufficient for climbing (Fig. 1 right). An additional result of the project, in collaboration with Duke University, was a new approach to greatly increase the numerical efficiency of dynamic simulations of robot hands with many spine contacts on hard surfaces.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project was part of a collaboration among Duke University, U.C. Santa Barbara and Stanford to develop hardware and control and motion planning software to enable a human-scale multi-limbed robot to traverse difficult terrain including steep slopes and nearly vertical rock faces. The specific goal of the Stanford contribution was to develop novel end-effectors and related control and sensing methods that enable a heavy, legged robot to climb steep rocky surfaces. The hardware and software were tested initially at Stanford and later at NASA JPL. The project culminated in the design and fabrication of a new end-effector for the RoboSimian quadruped at JPL. The end-effector design employs a combination of spines on the phalanges of fingers and on a particle-jamming palm that conforms to rough surfaces (Fig. 1, left). The spines make contact with asperities (small bumps or pits) on the rock surface to generate high shear forces with little normal force. However, each spine/surface contact can only sustain a small fraction of the required load for a heavy robot. Therefore, the end-effector has mechanisms for load-sharing both among the phalanges and among spines in the compliant palm. The two load sharing mechanisms are focused on the fingers and palm of the hand respectively. The phalanges are actuated through the use of a six-way tendon differential based on the concept of a whiffletree mechanism (Fig. 2). One tendon routes to each phalange, applying an approximately equal force to each array of spines. To promote load sharing among spines in the palm, we use a change of state as the granular medium in the palm switches from fluid to solid, under vacuum. The palm is first pressed into contact with the surface to be grasped and then lightly loaded in the shear direction. This causes small displacements along the surface, allowing the embedded microspines to travel until they find asperities. Next, a vacuum is applied to the central chamber, locking the palm into a rigid state and greatly increasing the stiffness of the spine supports via particle jamming (Fig. 3). This process helps to ensure that a substantial fraction of the spines is engaged, thereby increasing the maximum palm forces available for climbing. Tests conducted at JPL on the Surrogate platform (a two-armed variant of RoboSimian) confirm that the end-effector can sustain large tangential forces on surfaces, sufficient for climbing (Fig. 1 right). An additional result of the project, in collaboration with Duke University, was a new approach to greatly increase the numerical efficiency of dynamic simulations of robot hands with many spine contacts on hard surfaces.
